'Sir Francis Galton', FRS (; 16 February 1822 â 17 January 1911), cousin of
Douglas Strutt Galton, cousin of Charles Darwin, was an English Victorian
polymath: anthropologist, eugenicist, tropical explorer, geographer, inventor,
meteorologist, proto-geneticist, psychometrician, and statistician. He was
knighted in 1909.

Galton produced over 340 papers and books. He also created the statistical
concept of correlation and widely promoted regression toward the mean. He was
the first to apply statistical methods to the study of human differences and
inheritance of intelligence, and introduced the use of questionnaires and
surveys for collecting data on human communities, which he needed for
genealogical and biographical works and for his anthropometric studies.

He was a pioneer in eugenics, coining the term itself and the phrase "nature
versus nurture". His book Hereditary Genius (1869) was the first social
scientific attempt to study genius and greatness. Galton, F. (1869). [http://galton.org/books/hereditary-
genius/ Hereditary Genius]. London: Macmillan.

As an investigator of the human mind, he founded psychometrics (the science of
measuring mental faculties) and differential psychology and the lexical
hypothesis of personality. He devised a method for classifying fingerprints that
proved useful in forensic science. He also conducted research on the power of
prayer, concluding it had none by its null effects on the longevity of those
prayed for. http://www.abelard.org/galton/galton.htm

As the initiator of scientific meteorology, he devised the first weather map,
proposed a theory of anticyclones, and was the first to establish a complete
record of short-term climatic phenomena on a European
scale. [http://scienceworld.wolfram.com/biography/Galton.html Francis Galton
(1822â1911) â from Eric Weisstein's World of Scientific Biography ] He also invented the Galton Whistle for testing
differential hearing ability. Galton, Francis (1883). [http://www.galton.org/books/human-
faculty/index.html Inquiries into Human Faculty and Its Development]. London:
J.M. Dent & Co.
